title: 30 Best Immune-Boosting Foods - Nutrisense Journal
description: Check out 30 of the best immune-boosting foods you might want to add to your diet this winter.
cleaned_text: As the weather gets colder, you might [notice that you get sick](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4097773/) a little more often than usual. This is partially because cooler weather can [impair your immune system](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6561219/). Luckily, there are some ways you may be able to [combat cold and flu season](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/change-of-weather-sick) by boosting your immune system, and one of these ways is your diet! You've probably [heard that vitamin C is great](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5707683/) when you're under the weather. But there are a lot of other nutrients that can also be beneficial when it comes to immune health. Read on for 30 of the best immune-boosting foods you might want to add to your diet this winter, plus learn more about the impact your nutrition can have on your immune system. Can Your Diet Affect Your Immune System? The immune system is your body's [complex network](https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/cancer-terms/def/immune-system) of cells, organs, and tissues that work together to fight infection and disease. Your diet can play a huge role in [a healthy immune system](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6723551/), since every cell and metabolic process in your body needs adequate nutrition to function. The nutrients you consume through food [allow your immune cells to respond quickly](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9083862/) both to outside invaders, like viruses and bacteria, and avoid chronic inflammation. And when you do get sick, your body requires extra energy from food sources and your body's nutrition stores to fight off infection. There are many [vitamins, minerals, amino acids, and fatty acids](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/11-vitamins-minerals-lacking-in-american-diet) available from food sources that can boost your immune system, and each one can be beneficial in different ways. Aside from isolated nutrients, [dietary patterns as a whole](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7146186/) are very important to consider when appreciating the impact of diet on immune function. So, which foods can give your immune system a boost? Keep reading to find out. 30 Foods that May Boost Immune Health Here's our list of the 30 best immune-boosting foods to add to your diet. Stick around until the end for a breakdown of all the nutrients found in these foods and what the science says about their effects on immune health. Fruits and Vegetables - Citrus Fruits Citrus fruits, like oranges, grapefruit, lemons, and limes are excellent sources of vitamin C. A [single orange](https://www.nutritionix.com/food/orange) has about 138 percent of your daily recommended vitamin C intake, and a grapefruit [contains](https://www.nutritionix.com/food/grapefruit) 128 percent! - Tomatoes Tomatoes are another fruit full of vitamin C, and they also pack a significant amount of beta carotene. One medium tomato [contains](https://www.nutritionix.com/food/tomato) about 20 percent of your daily recommended vitamin A intake (in the form of beta-carotene), and 28 percent of your recommended vitamin C. - Red Bell Peppers You may be surprised to learn that red bell peppers have almost three times the vitamin C of an orange. One red bell pepper [contains](https://www.nutritionix.com/food/red-bell-pepper) 325 percent of your daily recommended vitamin C intake, as well as 67 percent of your recommended intake of vitamin A (in the form of beta-carotene). - Kiwi [Kiwifruit](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23394995/) contains vitamin C, carotenoids, polyphenols, and dietary fiber, all of which have beneficial effects on the immune system. Studies also show that they may reduce the incidence and [severity of upper respiratory tract ](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22172428/)infections. Kiwis are also rich in folate, a B vitamin that also [benefits the immune system](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1887065/). - Papaya Like many other fruits on this list, [papaya](https://www.nutritionix.com/food/papaya) is loaded with vitamin C—just one cup has 147 percent of your daily recommended value. It's also a [source of fiber](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/fiber-and-blood-sugar), beta-carotene, and folate. - Blueberries Blueberries are rich in antioxidants called [anthocyanins](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22111516/#:~:text=This%20study%20indicates%20that%20daily,and%20increases%20anti%2Dinflammatory%20cytokines.), which may help reduce oxidative stress and increase anti-inflammatory cytokines. They may also increase natural killer, or NK, cell count. [NK cells](https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/cancer-terms/def/natural-killer-cell) are immune cells that can kill tumor cells and cells infected with viruses. - Broccoli [Broccoli](https://www.nutritionix.com/food/raw-broccoli) is rich in beta-carotene and C, and also has a good amount of dietary fiber. It's important to note that vitamin C content may be diminished by prolonged heat or moisture exposure, in which case [the cooking method](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6049644/) may be good to consider. - Sweet Potatoes Sweet potatoes are packed with beta-carotene—one medium sweet potato [contains](https://www.nutritionix.com/food/sweet-potato) a whopping 438 percent of your daily recommended value. [Orange sweet potatoes](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/health-benefits-of-potatoes-sweet-potatoes-yams) are also rich in beta-carotene, and purple sweet potatoes are rich in anthocyanins. - Spinach Spinach is rich in beta-carotene and C: one cup of raw spinach [contains](https://www.nutritionix.com/food/spinach) 377 percent of your daily recommended vitamin A value, and 29 percent of your daily vitamin C requirement. Spinach also contains [antioxidants](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3999804/) that help fight free radicals and reduce oxidative stress. Spices and Herbs - Garlic Garlic contains [allicin](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4417560/), a compound that helps maintain the homeostasis of the immune system and stimulates macrophages, lymphocytes, natural killer cells, and other cells of the immune system. Studies also show that garlic may be able to [fight off viruses](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32836826/) by blocking viral entry into our cells. However, many of these studies were done on cell cultures in vitro and more research is needed for in vivo human studies. - Ginger Ginger contains many bioactive compounds, including gingerol, that may have powerful [antioxidant and anti-inflammatory](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3665023/) effects. It also has microbial properties that can help in the treatment of infectious disease. Like garlic and other bioactives, many of these studies were done in vitro and more thorough in vivo studies are needed. - Turmeric [Turmeric](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/does-turmeric-help-lower-blood-sugar), a bright yellow spice, contains [curcumin](https://www.hindawi.com/journals/bmri/2014/186864/), a polyphenic compound that may have antiviral, antifungal, and antimicrobial properties. Curcumin in moderate amounts has also [been shown in preliminary studies to modulate](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17211725/) the activation of B and T cells, macrophages, natural killer cells, and other cells of the immune system, though more research is needed. - Rosemary [Rosemary](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/health-benefits-of-herbs-and-spices) contains many [bioactive compounds](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7491497/), including rosmarinic acid and that have antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant properties. These bioactive compounds have primarily been studied in vitro and higher quality in vivo studies are needed to confirm these effects in the human body. - Fennel [Fennel](https://www.britannica.com/plant/fennel) is a flowering herb that is part of the carrot family. It contains [volatile oils](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8545060/) that have been shown to exhibit high anti-inflammatory properties in vitro. However, their effect on the immune system and neutrophil function is still uncertain. Nuts and Seeds - Almonds Almonds are [rich in vitamin E](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/VitaminE-HealthProfessional/), an antioxidant that prevents oxidative damage and fights off free radicals in your body. Vitamin E in adequate (but not excessive) amounts also [enhances the function of the immune system](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7011499/) and may reduce the risk of infection. It can improve T cell function, lymphocyte proliferation, and NK cell and macrophage activity. - Sunflower Seeds Sunflower seeds are also rich in vitamin E—just one ounce [contains](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/VitaminE-HealthProfessional/#h3) 49 percent of your daily recommended value. Vitamin E also seems to have an especially positive effect on [age-associated immune system dysfunction](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25244230/). - Walnuts Like sunflower seeds and almonds, walnuts are rich in vitamin E—100 grams provides 140 percent of your daily needs. Walnuts are also [rich in riboflavin](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25244230/) and folate. - Chia Seeds [Chia seeds](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6627181/) are another source of vitamin E, along with folate, riboflavin, and zinc. Here are some [dietitian-approved chia seed recipes](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/chia-seed-recipes) you can use to add more chia seeds to your diet. Other Foods - Yogurt Yogurt is a [fermented milk product](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/yogurt-and-blood-glucose) that is rich in active cultures, like the probiotics Lactobacillus and Bifidobacterium, which are shown to [enhance immunity](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11722966/). - Sauerkraut A [dairy-free fermented food alternative](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9003261/), sauerkraut is a traditional fermented form of cabbage that may offer probiotic support. However, as with all fermented foods and probiotic supplements, [not everyone may tolerate them](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4490230/). Some people may be more likely to experience negative side effects from higher or regular intake of these products. - Raw Honey Honey is [widely used](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5424551/#:~:text=%5B84%5D%20Honey%20has%20been%20indicated,cells%2C%5B87%2C88%5D) for its medicinal properties. It has been shown to [exert antioxidant, antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5424551/), and anticancer effects in vitro. It may also activate the immune response to injection and increase the creation of B and T cells, natural killer cells, antibodies, and other immune cells. However, more in vivo studies are needed to determine the effects in the human body. - Extra Virgin Olive Oil Studies show that olive oil is capable of [suppressing the immune system](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20204249/), which may improve inflammation and be beneficial for those with autoimmune disorders. Sometimes, this [suppression can have the unwanted effect](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20204249/) of also reducing protection against infectious microorganisms. Olive oil, however, has been shown to suppress the immune system [without reducing immune system resistance](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20204249/) to infections. However, more high-quality studies in vivo are needed. Protein - Chicken Chicken is a great source of protein, which is crucial for [immune system function](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2105184/). It is also a decent source of [vitamin B6](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/VitaminB6-HealthProfessional/): three ounces of chicken breast contains 29 percent of your daily value. Vitamin B6 has been shown to help [regulate inflammation](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5358464/) and promote B and T cell and hemoglobin formation. - Turkey Turkey is [another source of protein](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/protein-and-blood-sugar) and vitamin B6—three ounces contains 25 percent of your daily B6 needs. - Salmon Salmon is a good source of protein, as well as immune-boosting [vitamin D](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2698592/). A four-ounce portion of sockeye salmon contains around [800 IU of vitamin D](https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/175174/nutrients). Salmon is also rich in omega-3 fatty acids, which may beneficially [regulate](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6834330/) the activity of immune system cells. - Oysters Oysters are the [richest natural source](https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/foods-high-in-zinc) of zinc: just three raw oysters [contain](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Zinc-HealthProfessional/#h3) 291 percent of your daily recommended value, and three cooked oysters contain 256 percent. - Eggs Eggs are a [great source](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8310913/) of protein, as well as one of the few natural food sources of [vitamin D](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24114770/). Eggs also contain both provitamin A (beta-carotene) and preformed vitamin A, zinc, and many different types of B vitamins, including riboflavin. Drinks - Water Good hydration is essential to the maintenance of [every system](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2908954/) in your body. It helps [your body absorb and break down nutrients](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/hydration-strategies-recommended-by-dietitians), carries nutrients and oxygen to your cells, protects your organs and keeps them functioning, and regulates your body temperature. These are all important for a working immune system. - Ginseng Tea [Ginseng](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3659612/) is a root that has widely been used around the world for its medicinal properties. In certain amounts, it has been shown to help maintain homeostasis of the immune system, enhance resistance to illness and microbial attacks, and influence and control immune system cells. - Green tea Green tea is rich in [flavonoids](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5829151/), a type of antioxidant that has anti-inflammatory effects and may improve the balance of the gut microbiome. However, research in this area is very limited and more randomized controlled clinical trials are needed to understand how these bioactives modulate immune activity in the human body. Which Nutrients Can Boost Immunity? As you can see, there are many different foods that may have a positive impact on your immune health. However, while a number of [nutrients found in these foods have been shown](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9083862/) to support immunity, it's also important to consider that more of a beneficial food isn't always better. Researchers advise sticking to daily recommended doses for each nutrient, especially if you are taking [supplements](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/supplements-lower-your-blood-sugar). Higher-than-recommended intakes of any nutrient have [not been shown to confer additional health benefits](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9083862/) (and may even pose more risk at higher dosage). We'll talk more about this below! With that said, here are some of the most common nutrients found in the foods listed above that can support your immune health and help fight off infection. Vitamin C [Vitamin C](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5707683/) helps to maintain our immune system in a few ways. It supports the [epithelial barrier](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3246647/), which are the external surfaces of our gastrointestinal tracts, respiratory tracts, and skin that keep out invading microorganisms and pathogens. It also [promotes oxidant scavenging activity](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5707683/) of the skin, which protects against environmental oxidative stress. This vitamin can also [enhance differentiation and proliferation](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9083862/) of B and T cells, which are white blood cells that play important roles in the immune system, like destroying dangerous cells and producing antibodies. Vitamin C deficiency has been shown to [result in impaired immune function](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5707683/) and higher susceptibility to infections. There may be [decreased severity and duration](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6124957/) of colds when vitamin C is consumed at doses at or above 200 milligrams per day, with recommendations for people to obtain this primarily from their diet. For people exposed to brief severe periods of physical exertion, [supplemental vitamin C in higher amounts](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6124957/) has been shown to be immune-supportive. However, studies have shown that vitamin C supplementation [does not reduce](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6124957/) the incidence of colds in the general population. More high-quality randomized controlled trials are needed. As with any nutrient, more isn't always better. Higher dose vitamin C supplementation (1000 milligrams daily) in the form of ascorbic acid has been associated with an approximately [twofold increased risk of kidney stones](https://www.nature.com/articles/nrneph.2013.29#:~:text=Ascorbic%20acid%20supplement%20use%20was,associated%20with%20kidney%20stone%20risk.). Higher amounts of vitamin C may also act as [pro-oxidants](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7285147/), the opposite of their lower-dose antioxidant function. Vitamin D Vitamin D is another vitamin that helps maintain our immune systems. Vitamin D can [up-regulate anti-microbial peptides](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20119827/), which can help clear bacteria from barrier sites and immune cells. Like vitamin C, [vitamin D](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/the-best-diet-for-vitamin-d) also has an effect on T cell activation. Immune cells can also activate vitamin D in the body, which plays a role in [maintaining the homeostasis](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20427238/) of our immune system. Vitamin D deficiency has been shown to increase susceptibility to chronic infections and autoimmune diseases. Can you get too much vitamin D? The short answer is yes. Researchers know that vitamin D not only [supports immune health](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20427238/), but also can be good for bone health. However, a 2010 randomized controlled trial showed that intake of very high doses of vitamin D in older women was associated with [more falls and fractures](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/185854). Taking too much vitamin D in supplement form can lead to [hypercalcemia and toxicity](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5045493/). Hypercalcemia may result in calcium building up in the blood, arteries, and soft tissue. It may also result in higher risk for kidney stones. Studies show that the [short-term ingestion](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5045493/) of up to 10,000 IU/day of vitamin D3 is associated with the maintenance of 25(OH)D serum concentrations below 50 ng/mL (125 nmol/L). This is a serum concentration below which toxicity risk is very minimal. Each person may respond differently to [different doses of vitamin D](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/do-you-need-more-vitamin-d) supplements, so it's always important to work with your doctor when navigating the question of supplement dosage. Vitamin A [Vitamin A](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6162863/) has a critical role in enhancing immune system function. It is even involved in the development of our immune system. This vitamin plays a regulatory role in cellular immune response, and also helps in the [formation and maintenance](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10466169/) of the epithelial barrier. It is also an integral part of the mucus layer of the respiratory tract and the intestine, improving their immunity function. Retinoic acid, a form of vitamin A, can inhibit the development of inflammatory cells and [promote T cell activation](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4924190/). However, as with other nutrients discussed here, it's also possible to get too much of a good thing. [Vitamin A toxicity is a possibility](https://academic.oup.com/ajcn/article/83/2/191/4649798) with higher intakes. Some research suggests that [sub-toxicity without clinical signs of toxicity](https://academic.oup.com/ajcn/article/83/2/191/4649798) may be a growing concern as well and is more likely in individuals consuming multiple supplemental forms of vitamin A, including those from fortified food products. B Vitamins B vitamins are a group of vitamins that are involved in many functions, including: - Helping you get energy from food - Aiding cell growth and development - Supporting DNA production - Supporting nerve health They are also involved in immune system function, particularly [vitamin B2](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fimmu.2021.665968/full) (also called riboflavin). Vitamin B2 may also have [antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470460/), which can support immune health. It is also involved in T cell activation, differentiation, and proliferation. Adequate intake of B vitamins in general has also been shown to support the normal [activity of macrophages](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23415257/), which are cells that detect and fight off harmful bacteria. Beta-Carotene [Beta-carotene](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10604207/) is a carotenoid, which is a class of pigments that gives red, yellow, and orange vegetables their pigment. Beta-carotene is what is known as a [provitamin A carotenoid](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/VitaminA-Consumer/), which means it is turned into the retinol form of vitamin A in your body. In most cases, carotenoid sources must be converted to the retinol and related forms in order to be active in the body. However, the [immune-supportive effect](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/14704330/) of certain carotenoids may be partly independent of their provitamin A activity. Since larger studies [have not shown beneficial effects](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11684388/) of beta-carotene supplementation, more emphasis is placed on achieving optimal levels within a well-balanced diet. Zinc Zinc is a nutrient that in adequate amounts can [help your immune system](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Zinc-Consumer/) fight off invading bacteria and viruses. Zinc is important for the [normal development](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2277319/) and function of our immune cells. The antioxidant activity of zinc is thought to [prevent free-radical damage](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5488004/) and reduce inflammation in the body. Zinc deficiency has been [shown to adversely affect](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9083862/) the function of the immune system, in particular the growth and function of both T and B cells. However, in excessive amounts, zinc may actually [impair the immune system](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Zinc-Consumer/) as well as impair the body's utilization of copper. This is why it's important to ensure adequate, but not excessive zinc intake. Like with all vitamins and minerals, experts [recommend getting the majority](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6366563/) your zinc through whole food sources. Consult a [registered dietitian](http://nutrisense.io/dietitians) or medical professional for guidance before making significant dietary changes. Probiotics [Probiotics](https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/probiotics-what-you-need-to-know) are live microorganisms that live naturally in our bodies and are also found in various foods, like [yogurt](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/yogurt-and-blood-glucose) and [fermented foods](https://www.nutrisense.io/blog/the-health-benefits-of-fermented-foods). The most common bacteria found in probiotic products are Lactobacillus and Bifidobacterium. Probiotics affect both the [innate and adaptive immune system](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5995450/). They promote the production of bacteriocins, which can kill harmful bacteria, and short chain fatty acids, which can suppress inflammation. These microorganisms can lower the pH of the gut, making it [more acidic](https://guides.hostos.cuny.edu/bio140/6-24), which can aid in killing pathogens. They can also stimulate the function of the mucosal barrier and modify T cell responses, and [maintain homeostasis of cytokine responses](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3725482/). Protein Protein is [crucial for immune system](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fimmu.2021.665968/full) function. This is because amino acids, the molecules that form proteins, are essential for the [production of immune proteins](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9083862/), like cytokines and antibodies. Amino acids are involved in the [regulation and activation of T and B cells](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9083862/) and have also shown antioxidant activity. Protein deficiency is associated with an [impaired immune system](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2105184/), with particularly detrimental effects on the T cell system, which results in increased infections. [Related Article](#) Engage with Your Blood Glucose Levels with Nutrisense Your blood sugar levels can significantly impact how your body feels and functions. That's why stable blood glucose levels can be an important factor in supporting overall wellbeing.
